channel.title: jBCrypt for password encryption
channel.description:
http://www.mindrot.org/projects/jBCrypt/
Has anyone looked at using jBCrypt? I will play around with it some and see what I can accomplish but finding a good example of how to implement this would greatly help with the learning process if anyone has the time.

item.title: jBCrypt for password encryption
item.dc:creator: @teddybear13 teddybear13
item.description:
@teddybear13 wrote:

Try reading the doc. There’s an example right on the main page.

[code]// Hash a password for the first time
String hashed = BCrypt.hashpw(password, BCrypt.gensalt());

// gensalt’s log_rounds parameter determines the complexity
// the work factor is 2**log_rounds, and the default is 10
String hashed = BCrypt.hashpw(password, BCrypt.gensalt(12));

// Check that an unencrypted password matches one that has
// previously been hashed
if (BCrypt.checkpw(candidate, hashed))
System.out.println(“It matches”);
else
System.out.println(“It does not match”);
[/code]

Literally just plug it in your authentication layer…

Anyway to answer your question, bcrypt would be more than enough to cover most brute-force type attacks.

Read full topic

item.title: jBCrypt for password encryption
item.dc:creator: @Vain1 Vain_
item.description:
@Vain1 wrote:

disregarding the fact that this is rsc, what “good example” are you looking for? this can be used for passwords, just as easily as any other API.
